name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Here's the detailed picture for 2018  The drop in effective income tax rates at the top?   The product of: - A low capital gains tax rate (20%) - Tax avoidance (billionaires owning zero-dividend-paying companies & postponing capital gains realizations)  https://t.co/frcuji0QPe

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: It is my duty to note, once again, that taxes on the rich are at a historically low level in the United States today  https://t.co/kSBsBiy4Wg

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: < Wearing a nice tie > A 80% tax rate on crypto capital gains would reduce GDP growth by 2.2% ($779.1 billion cumulative loss in 2031), destroy 857,000 jobs, and make the US less competitive in the strategic industry of bitcoin mining

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Too bad ‚Äî as a hedge fund manager, he know a lot about 2% annual levies on assets    https://t.co/psCeDx5wSl

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Billionaires have $2.5 trillion in unrealized gains  Taxed at 40% this means...  <Dr Evil voice> one TRILLION dollars in revenue

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Increasing the capital gains tax rate is a good idea ‚Äî and the best way to make this work well is to combine it with a one-off tax on the stock of unrealized capital gains of billionaires, to prevent them from deferring realizations   https://t.co/2CkwAvcKmT

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: 4) It's utopian to imagine G20 countries agreeing to such a tax anytime soon  Answer:  https://t.co/Jd4HfFqc8R

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: 3) The tax would be bad for struggling businesses that make no or little profits  Answer: No, because the tax does not affect cash flows ‚Äî firms can always pay by issuing new shares, and if the stock price is low it means the tax owed is low too  https://t.co/27tSoGVmcB

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: 2) The tax would increase incentives for listed firms to issue debt (and reduce equity)  Answer: if this is a concern, tax corporate bonds just like equity  Easy to do: corporate bonds, like equities, are traded in highly centralized markets, with clear market values

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Some answers to the most frequent objections to our proposal for a corporate wealth tax ( https://t.co/Qb9V9x8Uo0)   1) The tax would create incentives for firms to remain private.   Answer:  https://t.co/E9Ds8WPRvQ

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: - Straightforward to collect - Hard to avoid, impossible to evade - Easy to pay (firms could always issue shares to pay the tax if they lack liquidity)  - Progressive  Let's do it!  Comments most welcome, as always  /end

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: And a wealth tax on corporations' stock, even at a flat rate of 0.2%, would be progressive  In the US, the top 1% highest earners have 19% of all income, but more than 30% of equity wealth (including equity wealth held through pension funds)  https://t.co/6RMcBdfp7T

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Equity wealth is a big & rising part of private wealth  We don't tax it, and instead tax housing ‚Äî supposedly because it's easier  But taxing equity wealth is in fact much simpler: there are clear market values, equity markets are highly centralized, SEC already collects fees  https://t.co/uXyc49nHZS

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Excited that our paper (with E. Saez), ‚ÄúA Wealth Tax on Corporations‚Äô Stock‚Äù, is now out!  Idea: a tax of 0.2% on the market value of big companies  - Hard to avoid - Firms can pay by issuing shares (if they lack liquidity) - Raise $180 billion annually   https://t.co/Qb9V9x8Uo0

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: This matters because, fundamentally, the corporate tax is a minimum tax for the very rich  Bezos, Buffett, Zuckerberg, etc can avoid the individual income tax by asking their companies not to pay dividends  But they still have to pay the corporate tax  Except now it's almost gone

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Post Trump tax reform, the United States collects less corporate income tax revenue (as a fraction of GDP) than all other OECD countries.  Even Hungary, with its 9% tax rate, does better than the US.  https://t.co/pF1qrLP9gJ

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: This is a really good idea, imho   https://t.co/2CkwAvcKmT

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: I'm always amazed by these polls ‚Äî wealth taxes are just incredibly popular   https://t.co/FxKsWJpLL0  https://t.co/2bBqZrHWB4

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: If it comes down to this, here's $1 trillion from taxing billionaires' unrealized capital gains ( https://t.co/OXo9NyQinW), and close to an extra $1 trillion by taxing the market value of listed corporations at 0.2% ( https://t.co/Qb9V9x8Uo0)

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Happy U.S. tax day!  To celebrate, here are ~two~ new tax proposals! üéâ  1. A wealth tax on corporations' stock:  https://t.co/Qb9V9x8Uo0  2. A one-off wealth tax on billionaires' unrealized capital gains:  https://t.co/OXo9NyQinW  Comments most welcome, as always

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Very excited to present our new paper (with Emmanuel Saez), "A Wealth Tax on Corporations' Stock" in just a few minutes  Paper is now live!   https://t.co/Qb9V9x8Uo0

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Ladies and gentlemen, the perfect tax:  - Straightforward to implement - Impossible to game - Does not distort behavior - Only on billionaires - Raises $1 trillion dollar now  üëáüëáüëá   https://t.co/2CkwAvcKmT

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: White paper discusses the motivation, implementation, scoring, interaction with other plans to reform capital gains taxation...   https://t.co/OXo9NyQinW  Comments welcome!  /End

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: The solution?   Tax the stock of unrealized capital gains of billionaires now  - Easy to implement and enforce (less than 1,000 taxpayers) - Clear precedent (one-time tax on foreign earnings of multinationals in 2017) - Big $$$ ($1 trillion) raised in the most progressive manner

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Why? Because they structure their affairs so as to have little taxable income  - Pay themselves low salaries - Instruct their companies not to pay dividends - Do not sell their shares - Borrow money to fund consumption (see Musk, Elon)   https://t.co/5iax2iE0zg

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Relative to GDP, the wealth of the 400 richest Americans has doubled since 2010  But despite the upsurge in their fortunes, America's billionaires contribute very little to the public coffers  https://t.co/40fR0onOA5

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: New, from Emmanuel Saez and me:  A plan to tax billionaires' unrealized capital gains  - Generates $1 trillion now - Addresses a key injustice in the US tax system - Is constitutional   Summary in the Washington Post, and a short thread  üëáüëáüëá   https://t.co/2CkwAvcKmT

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Washington state has no income tax, so billionaires like Gates, Bezos, Ballmer who live there currently pay essentially no state tax  A deafening silence, really

name: Gabriel Zucman

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: A straightforward explanation of this proposal for global minimum taxation is in our book "The Triumph of Injustice" chapter 6  A slightly more technical version of this proposal can be found here:  https://t.co/Sgg2rWzTzO  Time to collect the tax deficit of multinationals!

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Can't stress enough how important minimum taxation is  It means that if a US firm books profits in, say, Ireland (taxed at 5%), the US would collect an extra tax of 16% to arrive at 21%  If other countries police their multinationals in the same way, it's the end of tax havens

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: All great moves   ‚úÖBy far the most important goal should be a high minimum tax ‚Äî this changes globalization. All the rest is secondary  ‚úÖApportioning profits based on sales makes sense  ‚úÖComprehensive rules (for all sectors) way better than specific taxes on tech

name: Gabriel Zucman
tweet: Some people say "can't happen again bc many businesses are now organized as pass-throughs, not subject to the corporate tax"  However C-corp profits (subject to the corp tax) are still big: 9% of national income, only slightly less than in 1950-80 (12%)  So it could happen again

name: Gabriel Zucman

tweet: Biden corporate tax plan released today:  - Increase rate to 28% - Tax profits booked by US firms abroad at 21%, country by country - Calls for strong global minimum tax (with penalties for uncooperative countries)  If enacted, the development model of tax havens collapses
